comments.raw_text:
I've noticed that sometimes when I filter in a global search I don't get as many results as I expect. For example, I search for "review" and get 397 initial results. On the left, there's a filter for the participant "release" with "36" beside it. When I include that constraint, the search only has 26 results. The filter on the left still says 36, though.

This doesn't happen for all filters. It _seems_ to be that filters that are exact e-mail address (eg, bugzilla-daemon@mozilla.org) are accurate, and others are not.

I'm also not sure if the filter summary is inaccurate, or if the filter itself is not showing me everything it should.

comments.raw_text:
> I'm also not sure if the filter summary is inaccurate

you mean the "unfiltered", initial list that is displayed?

If you do two searches do you get the same results?
And does "show list" show all the messages that the filter list (search facet list) shows?

A.  search criteria:  user@somwhere  sometext 
    show list

B.  search criteria:  
    sometext
    then filtered on user@somwhere
    show list

comments.raw_text:
It's probably the de-duplication logic which happens at a very high level in the presentation logic.  If you have multiple copies of a message (ex: gmail, the mozilla mailing list snafus, etc.), the global database knows about them.  Because it looked dumb to show the duplicates in the list on the right, they get filtered out.

As Wayne says, I would expect all 36 to show up if you do "show as list".
comments.author: bugmail@asutherland.org
comments.creator: bugmail@asutherland.org
comments.text:
It's probably the de-duplication logic which happens at a very high level in the presentation logic.  If you have multiple copies of a message (ex: gmail, the mozilla mailing list snafus, etc.), the global database knows about them.  Because it looked dumb to show the duplicates in the list on the right, they get filtered out.

As Wayne says, I would expect all 36 to show up if you do "show as list".

In my case, "show as list" shows the same number of results as the filtered search.

Also, when I search for "review release@mozilla.com" (which is what I've been testing with all along), I get 94 results, but that's probably because there's other mail that matches both of those things, that's not addressed _to_ release@mozilla.com.
